steps.title: Choose a high-quality tea.
steps.content: Choose a high-quality tea. White tea is far more expensive than any other tea, so it's not likely you'll be consuming it daily, but the price is worth it for weekend treats or other special occasions. Considering that you're spending a lot, though, it's important to ensure that you're getting the best quality possible. White tea has two versions: a traditional budget white tea (Fujian Silver Needle, Anhui, etc.) and a modern new style leaf white tea. They are not interchangeable and appear very different. [3] X Research source White tea comes in several varieties, and they can differ significantly in price. Silver tip, jasmine silver tips, pai mu tan (white peony) and silver needle are the best varieties, [4] X Research source t leaf, White Tea, Information sheet and they are often also the most popular. You may even need to place an order with your local tea store to ensure that you get a supply each spring. If you're new to white tea, a good way to start is to buy a sampler kit from an online vendor. That way, you can try small amounts of several varieties to find your favorites. White tea can be bought as loose leaves or as teabags. However, if the container is opaque and if there is a lack of labeling, be careful as you might get leaf when all you wanted was buds, etc. Be sure to shop around to get the best deal possible. Since white tea is still relatively scarce, shopping online may be your best option.

steps.title: Purchase tea from the most recent harvest.
steps.content: Purchase tea from the most recent harvest. Ask the vendor to ensure that you're buying the most recent harvest , from the most recent northern hemisphere spring. Make sure that the tea you buy is packed in as airtight a container as possible. Keep it dry, cool, and dark to prevent oxidation. White tea doesn't keep for years like black tea does; it must be consumed within six months of purchase.

steps.title: Heat water to boiling, then let it cool for 5 to 8 minutes.
steps.content: Heat water to boiling , then let it cool for 5 to 8 minutes. Alternatively, only boil the water to "first boil". This is when the water begins to boil but has not yet begin to simmer. The temperature at this stage will be 160ºF (71ºC). Bitter brews come from too high a temperature of water on green tea; prefer a longer steeping time at a cooler temperature instead. If you live in an area with hard water, filter it before you use it to brew. Hard water may ruin white tea, which has very delicate flavors. Test the water temperature. Before adding the boiled water to the white tea, it should be no more than 158ºF to 167ºF (70ºC to 75ºC) or 160-170ºF (71-77ºC) at the most. [5] X Research source t leaf, White Tea, Information sheet [6] X Research source If the water is too hot, the tea will be scalded, causing it to become bitter and astringent.

steps.title: Add 2 teaspoons of white tea leaves per cup.
steps.content: Add 2 teaspoons of white tea leaves per cup. [7] X Research source t leaf, White Tea, Information sheet Place the tea leaves into a tea infuser basket, a tea ball, or a teapot. White tea leaves can withstand longer infusion times than other tea types before pouring. It is usual to steep for 7 to 10 minutes. [8] X Research source t leaf, White Tea, Information sheet However, you may wish to experiment with a short steep initially (1 to 3 minutes) and then to graduate to longer steeping times to find the steeping length you prefer. Use the same leaves for steeping several cups of white tea, with steeping times increasing as needed. Some sources recommend a 90 second to 2 minute steeping if you intend on steeping the leaves several times. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Serve the tea as it is.
steps.content: Serve the tea as it is. White tea should be served as it is, unadulterated. You may choose to pour milk or sugar in the white tea, but the already subtle flavor of the tea will be drowned out.
